Algoriphagus aurantiacus is capable of hydrolyzing various polysaccharides, such as agar, carrageenan, and starch, indicating its role in the degradation of complex organic matter in marine environments.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Algoriphagus aurantiacus is closely related to other members of the genus Algoriphagus, which are commonly found in marine and coastal habitats. The genus Algoriphagus is known for its ability to adapt to various environmental conditions, including salinity, temperature, and nutrient availability.

Overall, Algoriphagus aurantiacus is a marine bacterium that plays a role in the cycling of organic matter in aquatic ecosystems and contributes to the diversity of microbial communities in these environments.
